prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author was in the wrong here. So, the situation is about a friend who's been making a lot of comments that come off as insults. The friend has five kids with different fathers and has been divorced five times. She's been asking the author questions that are pretty demeaning, like implying that the author's success in dating is because she's skinny or a blonde.

The author tried to brush these off for two years by giving advice like focusing on oneself. Then, when the friend kept pushing, the author finally told her that having five kids with different dads might be making it hard to find someone. The friend got angry and hung up. Now the mutual friends are saying the author is being entitled and using skinny privilege, even though the author doesn't feel privileged.

Hmm. The key points here are the intent and the impact. The author's friend was being rude and making personal attacks. The author's response was honest and pointed out a fact that the friend's situation might be affecting her dating life. But the way it was said might have come across as harsh, even if it's true. The author's friend might have felt attacked, especially if the friend was already sensitive about her situation. 

Also, the author mentioned that the friend tried to do the same job in the adult industry but failed. Maybe the author's comment about child support was a valid point, but perhaps there's a better way to approach it. However, the friend's behavior was pretty toxic with all the insults. The author was defending themselves and pointing out a real issue. 

The mutual friends are taking the friend's side, but maybe they didn't see the context of the insults the author was receiving. The author might not be in the wrong because they were finally standing up for themselves after enduring two years of negativity. It's possible the comment was harsh, but it was a truthful observation. So, I think the answer is B, the author is not in the wrong. They were responding to ongoing insults with the truth, even if the delivery could have been softer.
